skill.name: accessibility-fundamentals
skill.description: Auto-invoke when reviewing JSX with interactive elements, forms, buttons, or navigation. Enforces WCAG compliance and inclusive design.
skill.summary: Reviews JSX components for WCAG compliance. Checks keyboard accessibility, semantic HTML, ARIA labels, form labels, and focus management.
skill.author: DanielPodolsky

security_audit.summary: All 63 static findings are false positives. The scanner misinterpreted markdown code block delimiters as shell execution, ARIA attributes as cryptographic patterns, and CSS color hex values as IP addresses. This is a legitimate accessibility documentation skill containing only static guidance and code examples.

content.value_statement: Many developers unintentionally create barriers for users with disabilities. This skill provides a systematic checklist for reviewing JSX components against WCAG guidelines, ensuring your code is inclusive and legally compliant.
actual_capabilities: Reviews JSX components for keyboard accessibility (Tab, Enter, Space)
Validates semantic HTML usage (buttons vs div onClick)
Checks form labels and ARIA attributes for screen readers
Identifies missing alt text on images
Reviews focus management and visible focus indicators
Provides WCAG 2.1 compliance checklist for interactive elements
limitations: Does not run automated accessibility tests like axe-core
Cannot validate color contrast ratios (requires visual inspection)
Does not test with actual screen readers

use_cases.title: Code Review for React Components
use_cases.description: Before merging pull requests, invoke this skill to verify new interactive components meet accessibility standards. Catches issues like missing labels, div-as-button anti-patterns, and poor focus management.

use_cases.title: Learning Inclusive Design Patterns
use_cases.description: New team members use this skill to understand accessibility requirements. The skill provides concrete examples of accessible vs inaccessible code patterns with explanations.

use_cases.title: Accessibility Audit for Features
use_cases.description: Before launching new features, use this skill to verify compliance with accessibility requirements. Covers modals, forms, navigation menus, and dynamic content updates.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Component Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this JSX component for accessibility issues. Check for keyboard accessibility, proper form labels, semantic HTML, and screen reader support.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you have a single component to review quickly

prompt_templates.title: Form Accessibility Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this form component. Check that every input has a label, error messages are linked with aria-describedby, and required fields are marked appropriately.
prompt_templates.scenario: When reviewing form components with multiple inputs

prompt_templates.title: Modal Dialog Audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Check this modal component. Verify focus trapping works, escape key closes it, keyboard focus is managed, and it has proper ARIA attributes.
prompt_templates.scenario: When reviewing modal or dialog components

prompt_templates.title: Navigation Menu Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this navigation component. Check keyboard navigation works, active states are announced, and menu structure is semantic.
prompt_templates.scenario: When reviewing navigation, menus, or dropdowns

output_examples.output:
This element has accessibility issues:
1. Not keyboard accessible - div elements don't respond to Enter/Space keys
2. Not announced as a button by screen readers
3. Missing semantic role

Fix: Use <button> element instead:
<button onClick={handleSubmit} className="submit-btn">Submit</button>

This input lacks accessibility:
1. No visible label - placeholder disappears when typing
2. Screen readers cannot announce purpose

Fix options:
<label>
  Email
  <input type="email" placeholder="Enter your email" />
</label>

Or:
<label htmlFor="email">Email</label>
<input id="email" type="email" placeholder="Enter your email" />

Icon-only buttons need accessible names:
1. Screen readers announce as "button" with no context

Fix: Add aria-label:
<button aria-label="Delete item">
  <TrashIcon aria-hidden="true" />
</button>

best_practices: Use native semantic elements (<button>, <a>, <input>) instead of divs with event handlers
Every form input must have a visible, associated label
All interactive elements must be keyboard accessible with visible focus states
anti_patterns: Using <div onClick> instead of <button> - breaks keyboard and screen reader support
Removing outline: none without replacement - leaves keyboard users lost
Using color alone to convey information - fails for colorblind users

faq.question: What is the minimum color contrast ratio for text?
faq.answer: Normal text requires 4.5:1 contrast ratio against the background. Large text (18px bold or 24px regular) requires 3:1 ratio.

faq.question: How do I make a modal accessible?
faq.answer: Trap focus within the modal while open, return focus to trigger element when closed, include Escape key to close, and add aria-modal="true".

faq.question: What is the first rule of ARIA?
faq.answer: No ARIA is better than bad ARIA. Use native semantic HTML first. Only add ARIA when HTML cannot express what you need.

faq.question: How do I test accessibility without tools?
faq.answer: Navigate your entire page using only Tab and keyboard. Verify you can complete all actions, focus is always visible, and you cannot get trapped.

faq.question: What is focus-visible and when should I use it?
faq.answer: focus-visible shows focus indicators only when navigating by keyboard, hiding them for mouse users. Use :focus-visible for best of both worlds.

faq.question: How do I make error messages accessible?
faq.answer: Link errors to inputs with aria-describedby, set aria-invalid="true" on invalid inputs, and use role="alert" or aria-live for announcements.
